column2: The Possibilites of Privatization

The economy is a wreck and has been since 1905. There is nothing we can do to change this, it is a fact of Bolivian life. Although, we may be able to gain profit for ourselves if we privatized many industries like water, energy, transportation and electricity. This may make life harder for the people, but we'll profit.
If it doesnt turn a quick buck, put it up for sale!
column9: Нужно поспешить с продажей всего этого!

column2: This is a betrayal of the Bolivian people!
Unemployment and The Class Division in Bolivia
column9: Безработица и классовое расслоение в Боливии

column2: Since the privatization of virtually every industry in Bolivia, the middle class has been destroyed and now everyone is either as poor as a native or a member of the mega-rich. There are little to no jobs left in Bolivia, and the jobs that still exist don't provide acceptable wages or benefits.
There is nothing we can do
The Natives and the Lower Class

There is growing discontent among the poor, who can't find shelter or feed their families. Many of them have formed shanty towns in the hillsides. The indiginous people, having to fend completely for themselves have also begun to complain.
column9: В последнее время растет недовольство бедных слоев населения, которые не могут найти приют и прокормить свои семьи. Многие из них создали трущобы на склонах холмов. Коренное население, брошенное на произвол судьбы, тоже начинает проявлять недовольство.

column2: Bah, Let them eat Empanadas!
Peru has proposed union between our nations

Some of them could be converted into troopships or gunboats, or even into light cruisers. A few politicians, however, think that we could use the harbour better by keeping it simply to civilian purposes.

Today the Brazilian Workers Confederation, led by Astrogildo Pereira, announced a major strike in Sгo Paulo. All the industry has stopped producing as most of the city's workers have joined the movement. The picketers are demanding a complete review of the labour laws, instituting a common minimal wage for all states and other workers rights. The organization is willing to negotiate starting now.

Berlin crisis is approaching Brazil

Suspend convertibility of the Brazilian Real
Effects of the Berlin crisis

Following the Berlin panic, the Brazilian government has decided to stick to its policies of pleasing foreign creditors by maintaining convertibility according to the principles defended by the European and North American bankers who set the terms for our country's relations with the world economy. These acts have left the regime even more alienated from just about every segment of society.
Thanks god we're leaving this mess already
Bank panic!

Due to our horrible decision of suspending convertibility of the Real, a huge part of the middle classes and industrialists are running to the banks and withdrawing their deposits fearing the bankruptcy of these institutions. Many economists are now fearing even greater effects of the Berlin crisis in Brazil.
Why does this always happens to us?

column2: New economical policies?

It's been almost an year since the beginning of the Berlin Crisis, and the effects of the horrible decisions of the previous government are still being felt by the Brazilian public. Unemployment is still rising, companies are going bankrupt every day and foreign capital is fleeing our country. We must now decide whether it would be better to make some interventions on the economy or if we should let the good old invisible hand do its job.
Free market has always been our way, stick to it
Some public interference in the economy may be needed
Privatize the public assets?
Laissez faire, laissez passer - Put everything on sale
Privatization would be a betrayal of the Brazilian people
The state needs at least SOME control - Establish mixed-capital ventures
Intervene on private companies?

With a great deal of private companies going bankrupt, unemployment is rising in Brazil. We should be assuming control of these enterprises before their bad handling harm our economy even more! Or we could at least promote some public-private partnerships and mixed-capital ventures, if we fear too much interventionism.
If they can't do anything right, we should buy everything
The state needs just SOME control - Promote some mixed-capital ventures
NATIONALIZATION IS SOCIALISM. Got it? Stay out of it!
Dealing with the trade unions

Most trade unions in Brazil are organized into the CBT and BOC syndicates. Behind their facade of fighting to improve workers' rights and wages, they are really an organization of undemocratic socialists who would take the first opportunity to topple our government and establish their dictatorship. As most of our workers are members of these unions, however, any move against them would be capable of triggering major unrest. What should we do?
Infiltrate our security agents on the unions
Crackdown - We can't allow them to operate
Let them operate freely
Outlaw the socialist parties?

As we have already taken actions against the trade unions and syndicates, some within our government propose a complete outlaw of any and all socialist and syndicalist political parties and organizations.
Of course - Get rid of this syndicalist scum
No way, this is a democracy!
Socialist protests in Sгo Paulo

Syndicalist groups led by Astrogildo Pereira are organizing major protests in downtown Sгo Paulo. They are rallying against the present economical policies which, according to them, are unable to fight the growing unemployment. Should we allow them to procceed?
They are a threat to democracy - Don't allow it
Let it procceed - This is a democracy after all
Landless peasants occupy a farm in Paranб
column9: Безземельные крестьяне захватили ферму в Паране

column2: The police will deal with them
Let the army do the job
If they need this land, just give it to them
column9: Если им нужна эта земля, просто дайте ее им

column2: Unemployment on the rise
Unemployment rates in the country are rising day by day. With support to our regime amongst the lower classes diminishing, dissent is growing.
column9: Уровень безработицы в стране растет с каждым днем. Поддержка нашему режиму среди низшего класса падает.

column2: Oh, well
Integralists and Syndicalists clash in Rio
column9: Столкновения интегралистов и синдикалистов в Рио

column2: Crackdown on both groups
Investigate the Integralist leaders only
The police will raid Socialist meetings only
May Day Protests

Today is the 1st of May, international workers' day. The Brazilian proletarians, however, have little to celebrate. The people has been dealing with rampant unemployment and major companies going bankrupt. The CBT syndicate under Astrogildo Pereira has called for several rallies to take place today on all major Brazilian cities.
Just ignore them
Send the cops - Crackdown on the trade unions
Astrogildo Pereira arrested

This morning, syndicalist leader Astrogildo Pereira was arrested in Rio de Janeiro on charges of treason and incitation to civil disorder. What shall we do now that we have one of the main oppositors to our government in our hands?
Lock him in jail - That'll teach those syndies
That's not enough - Exile him
Maybe that's just too much - Release him
The unsellable coffee

The coffee planters of Sгo Paulo have approached us. Due to the Berlin crisis, coffee prices are falling day by day on the international markets, and farms in the other southern states are filling their warehouses with more and more unsellable harvests. According to our economists, if we don't do something, the agricultural crisis will get worse and will soon affect other sectors of the economy. Since the landowners are our political allies, there's no reason to turn our backs on them.
If we help them, we will compromise our budget for other areas
column9: Если мы им поможем, то у нас возникнут трудности с бюджетом других областей

column2: Buy the surplus coffee and BURN it. That will raise its price!
column9: Купите излишек кофе и сожгите его!

column2: A Land Reform Programme?
Nonsense!
Set up a comission
Land reform programme under fire
Maybe we should revaluate our position
Keep up the comission
Land reform initiated

Our Land Reform Comission has produced a report detailing a plan for land redistribution in Brazil. It proposes the government buying unused land from the grand farmers by fair market prices, and redistributing it among the poorer peasants. This will somewhat increase our agricultural output and ease some tensions with the radical left, but may trigger some unwanted effects with the landed oligarchs.
Maybe we should back off
Sign it into law
New economical policies?

It's been almost an year since the beginning of the Berlin Crisis, and the effects of the horrible decisions of the previous government are still being felt by the Brazilian public. Unemployment is still rising, companies are going bankrupt every day and foreign capital is fleeing our country. We must now decide whether it would be better to make some interventions on the economy or if we should let the good old invisible hand do its job.
Free market has always been our way, stick to it
Some public interference in the economy may be needed
Privatize the public assets?
Put everything on sale
That would be a betrayal of our people
Intervene on private companies?
With a great deal of private companies going bankrupt, unemployment is rising in Brazil. We should be assuming control of these enterprises before their bad handling harm our economy even more!
We should buy everything
We must not antagonize the industrialists
Landless peasants occupy farm in Paranб
The police will deal with them
If they need this land, just give it to them
column9: Если им нужна эта земля, просто дайте ее им

column2: New directions for the military
A recent meeting of the Brazilian High Command has come to the conclusion that we need a clear new path of development for our army. Each of our top commanders has come up with a different proposal.
column9: На последней встрече бразильского верховного командования было сделано заключение о необходимости нового пути развития армии. Мнения о будущем направлении кардинально разделились.

column2: Eurico Gaspar Dutra - Defensive doctrine
Miguel Costa - Review our supplying schemes
Manuel Lima Nascimento - Tanks are the future of warfare
Keep everything as it is, we have more to worry about

column2: Unemployment rising

Unemployment rates in the country are rising day by day. With support to our regime amongst the lower classes diminishing, dissent is growing. Now may be the time for a review of our economic policies.
The state must have more control over the economy
Hand more power to the private initiative
Keep everything as is, it will give results eventually
May Day Protests

Today is the 1st of May, international workers' day. The Brazilian proletarians, however, have little to celebrate. The disastrous economical policies of our government have so far brought none of the promised effects. Instead, the people has been dealing with rampant unemployment and major companies going bankrupt. The CBT syndicate under Astrogildo Pereira has called for several rallies to take place today on all major Brazilian cities.
Just ignore them
Send the cops - crackdown on the trade unions
The unsellable coffee
Didn't they always believe in 'free market'? Ignore them!
column9: Разве они не всегда верят в 'свободный рынок'? Игнорируйте их!

column2: Buy the surplus coffee and BURN it. That will raise its price!
column9: Купите излишек кофе и сожгите его!

column2: A Land Reform Programme?
Nonsense!
Set up a comission!
Land reform programme under fire

A group of coronйis, the traditional landed oligarchs of the northeastern states, has met today in Fortaleza, Cearб, and expressed their concern over our land reform programme and promise to fight 'by any means necessary' for the integrity of their lands.
Maybe we should revaluate our position
Let them complain - Keep up the comission
Sign the land reform into law!

Our Land Reform Comission has produced a report detailing a plan for land redistribution in Brazil. The plan envisions the government buying unused land from the grand farmers by fair market prices and redistributing it among the poorer peasants. This will somewhat increase our agricultural output and ease some tensions with the radical left, but may trigger some unwanted effects with the landed oligarchs.
Maybe we should back off
Sign it into law
New economical policies?

It's been almost an year since the beginning of the Berlin Crisis, and the effects of the horrible decisions of the previous government are still being felt by the Brazilian public. Unemployment is still rising, companies are going bankrupt every day and foreign capital is fleeing our country. Integralist doctrine says that we should attempt intervention on the economy. Shall we proceed, or it would be better if we let the good old invisible hand do its job?
Free market has always been our way, stick to it
Public interference in the economy is needed more than ever!
The role of the industrialists on Integralism
They have no role in the Integralist state
Something like a Chamber of Corporations? Yeah, we'll think about it!
Dealing with the trade unions
We must get rid of these socialist organizations
Replace their leadership with loyal proletarians
They will have an important place on Integralist society
New directions for the military

A recent meeting of the Brazilian High Command has come to the conclusion that we need a clear new path of development for our army. Many of our top-level commanders has come up with a different proposal.
Eurico Gaspar Dutra - Defensive doctrine
Miguel Costa - Review our supplying schemes
Djalma Dutra - Tanks are the future of warfare
Keep everything as it is, we have more to worry about
column9: Оставьте все как есть, нам не о чем беспокоиться

column2: Outlaw the socialist parties?

One of our senators has proposed legislation which outlaws all political organizations the government decides to label as 'socialist'. This would effectively move all serious opposition to our government underground. However, some elements of our cabinet think we should be very cautious now. A persecution of our opposition would alienate the tenuous support we have from the workers and the middle classes.
Of course! Get rid of this syndicalist scum!
Now is not yet the time
The Patrianovistas
These Traditionalists can be useful - Integrate them on the AIB
Church boys? How can they be any useful? Ignore them!
The Arcbishop of Sгo Paulo supports the AIB

Dom Duarte Leopoldo e Silva, the arcbishop of Sгo Paulo, has congratulated the government on our decision to integrate the Patrianovistas into our Party. 'Catholicism is a part of Brazilian society since its beginning', he said. 'Having a government that will trully support the ideals of the Church will be a bless to this country'. So, we now are sure to have a greater support base for our policies.
See, I told you it would be a good idea
Alliance with Bolivia?

The world is a dangerous place, so we need alliances with sworn enemies of the capitalism. Bolivia and Brazil could benefit from joining forces in a crusade for a new, brave world. Anti-socialist warmongers from La Plata are seeking war to crush the successful Brazilian and Bolivian revolutions, so we need to combine our powers to defend the spoils of our proletarian uprisings!
Send proposition
There is no need for alliance
Alliance with Brazil?
Syndicalist Brazil needs allies to crush the burgeois La Plata. Do we want to sign an alliance with Brazil knowing that they can involve us into new local war?
Alliance between Brazil and Bolivia is formed
The Bolivian state expressed its intention to join our alliance. For the world revolution !
Welcome!!
Revolution in Bolivia!

A few months ago, the rightfull government of the Republic of Bolivia has been overthrown by syndicalist bands! Already their president has seeked asylum in La Plata. We must find a way to prevent this rebellion from spreading towards us. Our military leaders have suggested increasing our presence in the border areas.
Raise new troops in the area
Do nothing, they can't harm us
Emergency in Rio - Vargas attempts a coup

Shocking news have just arrived from our capital as we learn that defeated presidential candidate Getъlio Vargas has gathered a few hundred followers in downtown Rio de Janeiro. What appeared to be a simple protest turned into a coup attempt, as an army unit showed up on the scene in support of Vargas. The mob is now threatening to invade the Palбcio do Catete and depose our government!
The presidential guard will disperse these reactionaries
Stand down, we cannot endorse a bloodbath
The coup succeedes
Long live the new President!
Emergency in Rio - Prestes attempts a coup

Shocking news have just arrived, as we learn that tenentista leaders Isidoro Dias Lopes and Luнs Carlos Prestes have gathered a militia of workers and peasants and are now marching towards downtown Rio de Janeiro. According to our reports, the mob plans to take the Palбcio do Catete by force and depose our government!
The presidential guard will disperse these bandits
Stand down, we cannot endorse a bloodbath
The coup succeedes
Long live the new President!
Emergency in Rio - Integralists attempts a coup

Shocking news just arrived, as we learn that defeated presidential candidate Plнnio Salgado has gathered a few hundred followers in downtown Rio de Janeiro. What appeared to be a simple protest turned into a coup attempt, as an army unit showed up on the scene in support of him. The mob is now threatening to invade the Palбcio do Catete and depose our government!
The presidential guard will disperse these rebels
Stand down, we cannot endorse a bloodbath
The coup succeedes
Long live the new President!
Emergency in Rio - Prestes attempts a coup

Shocking news came from our capital today, as we learn that tenentista leaders Isidoro Dias Lopes and Luнs Carlos Prestes have gathered a militia of workers and peasants and are now marching towards downtown Rio de Janeiro. According to our reports, the mob plans to take the Palбcio do Catete by force and depose our government!
The presidential guard will disperse the syndie scum
Stand down, we cannot endorse a bloodbath
The coup succeedes
Long live the new President!
Vargas launches an uprising
Can't we have just one moment of calm? That's all I'm asking!
Massacre of the peasants
The conservative forces are invading all the lands reserved for our land reform programmes. There are reports of massacres of peasants all across Bahia by the jagunзos!
They will be avanged!
Rebels initiate a crackdown on trade unions

In the major industrial centres, rebel militias have started a crackdown on all the workers' organizations! Hundreds of proletarians have so far been murdered, and many more are fleeing the persecution!
We will find those criminals!
Government overthrown - Rio occupied by rebels!
They're coming! Run to the hills!
Reinforcing our authority
In order to legitimize our new regime, we must send our troops to those states that saw combat during the war, to ensure the governors of our mutual support.
Good
The new cabinet
Great!
Plнnio Salgado launches an uprising
Can't we have just one moment of calm? That's all I'm asking!
Government overthrown - Rio de Janeiro occupied by rebels
They're coming! Run to the hills!
Reinforcing our authority
In order to legitimize our new regime, we must send our troops to those states that saw combat during the war, to ensure the governors of our mutual support.
Good
The new cabinet
Great
Revolution! Prestes launches an uprising!
Can't we have just one moment of calm? That's all I'm asking!
Farms occupied in Bahia

The syndicalist mobs have started attacking and occupying the grand farms in Bahia. According to them, these lands have been seized 'from the oppresing oligarchs and will be distributed to the peasants of Brazil once the present Revolution is over'.
We will evict them from there!
Crackdown on the Integralists
The socialist bandits have initiated a general persecution of Integralists on the lands they now occupy!
They will be avenged!
Factories seized in Sгo Paulo
The syndicalist mobs have seized major factories in the state of Sгo Paulo. According to them, these industries shall now serve the state and the people!
We must protect the sacred right to private property
Government overthrown - Rio de Janeiro occupied by rebels

Tragedy has struck Brazil! The socialist-military uprising initiated by Luнs Carlos Prestes has reached their most uninmaginable objetive. Rebel forces under their command have reached our capital! Despite the resistance of the loyal security forces, an advanced party of militiamen entered the Palбcio do Catete, only to find it deserted. Our cabinet has fled to the mountain areas of the state, and from there will seek asylum abroad.
They're coming! Run to the hills!
Reinforcing our authority
In order to legitimize our new regime, we must send our troops to those states that saw combat during the war.
Good
The new cabinet

As Luнs Carlos Prestes and Isidoro Dias Lopes entered the Palбcio do Catete, they delivered a long speech before the Senate announcing the formation of a new provisional military government in substitution of the previous presidency. 'A new government that will change Brazil to a course towards progress and socialism', they say.
Great!
The President's Speech
Our president has delivered an emergency speech today calling for national unity against the rebel forces!
He's right, you know
The uprising spreads!

Despite our best efforts, we still haven't been able to crush this uprising. Rebel forces now have spread even further north, to Manaus. One band of rebels has overthrown the city government and defeated our local garrison, a move that will put the whole Amazon in jeopardy.
Like if we hadn't anything else to worry about
Elections postponed
Our president has announced that the next presidential elections, which were scheduled for 1940, have been postponed until 1942 due to the present conflict.
Too bad!
Lampiгo is at our disposal
Cangaceiro leader Lampiгo has put his men at our disposal.
One piece of good news, at least
Form Workers' Militias?

As tens of thousands of workers all over Brazil have volunteered to join the armed forces, trade union leaders have proposed the formation of a number of proletarian militias to defend our socialist government.
The people will fight for their freedom
We must spare the workers
Military sides with the government

Our Chiefs of Staff announced today that the armed forces will continue to side with the government in the present internal conflict. Despite some elements of the military having sympaties with the reactionary rebels, these have been mostly neutralized. While a small number has defected and joined the rebel forces, the bulk of the Army and Navy will respect their commanders and keep their loyalty to us.
Great!
The Second Army joins the rebels

Despite an announcement this morning by our Chiefs of Staff that the armed forces would continue to side with the government in the present internal conflict, the Second Brazilian Army (Segundo Exйrcito Brasileiro) has defected to the rebels! Although the High Command have assured us that most reactionary-sympatizing commanders of the Army and Navy have been replaced or otherwise neutralized, we must remain vigilant as more units may end up stabbing us in the back!
What else, now?
Call up the Forзas Pъblicas

The Forзas Pъblicas, the Brazilian State Polices, are, according to our Constitution, a reserve force of the Army. Thus, they could be called up by the federal government to supress this present conflict. Some states may refuse to cede their forces, however, as these men may see better use in preventing unrest on their own home states.
We need all the help we can get!
They're policemen, not soldiers, leave them be

They're policemen, not soldiers, leave them be
Batalhгo Patriуtico Chapada Diamantina
The northeastern oligarchs have set up a number of 'Patriotic Batallions' (Batalhхes Patriуticos), made up of their jagunзo thugs. They are willing to offer us their services!
They may be useful!
we need no help from their kind
Military sides with the government

Our Chiefs of Staff announced today that the armed forces will continue to side with the government in the present internal conflict. Despite some elements of the military having sympaties with the reactionary rebels, these have been mostly neutralized. While a small number has defected and joined the rebel forces, the bulk of the Army and Navy will respect their commanders and keep their loyalty to us!

Although our High Command have assured us that most rebel-sympatizing commanders of the Army and Navy have been replaced or otherwise neutralized, we must remain vigilant as more units may end up stabbing us in the back!
Oh, great

Thus, they could be called up by the federal government to supress this present conflict. Some states may refuse to cede their forces, however, as these men may see better use in preventing unrest on their own home states.
Call them up, we need all the help we can get
They're policemen, not soldiers, leave them be
Greenshirts are called up
Our party's paramilitary arm, the Camisas-Verdes (Greenshirts) have been called up to defend our regime!
Great!
Military sides with the government

Our Chiefs of Staff announced today that the armed forces will continue to side with the government in the present internal conflict. Despite some elements of the military having sympaties with the reactionary rebels, these have been mostly neutralized. While a small number has defected and joined the rebel forces, the bulk of the Army and Navy will respect their commanders and keep their loyalty to us!
Great!
The Second Army joins the rebels

Despite an announcement this morning by our Chiefs of Staff that the armed forces would continue to side with the government in the present internal conflict, the Second Brazilian Army (Segundo Exйrcito Brasileiro) has defected to the rebels! Although our High Command have assured us that most rebel-sympatizing commanders of the Army and Navy have been replaced or otherwise neutralized, we must remain vigilant as more units may end up stabbing us in the back!
Oh, great
The end of the Brazilian Civil War
Peace has returned to our land as government forces have defeated the rebels in all their remaining strongholds. Now here comes the reconstruction...
That will take some time
The end of the Brazilian Civil War
Peace has returned to our land as government forces have defeated the rebels in all their remaining strongholds. Now here comes the reconstruction...
That will take some time
The end of the Brazilian Civil War
Peace has returned to our land as government forces have defeated the rebels in all their remaining strongholds. Now here comes the reconstruction...
That will take some time
The end of the Brazilian Civil War
Peace has returned to our land as government forces have defeated the rebels in all their remaining strongholds. Now here comes the reconstruction...
That will take some time
Civil War in Brazil
The Syndicalist government of Brazil is facing an uprising of rebels under Getъlio Vargas. We could use the chance to support them and further weaken those socialist bandits!
Support the rebels - Smuggle arms into Mato Grosso do Sul
These Getulistas are as dangerous as Syndicalists, do nothing
La Plata supports the rebels!
The reactionary government of La Plata has started smuggling arms and supplies to a large rebel band in Mato Grosso do Sul. We now have to open another front of our operations...
Those bastards!
Demobilize the Workers' Militias
Send these men back to their civilian lives
These loyal men will become the elite of our army
Purging the Military

During the civil war, a great number of our officers sided with the reactionary forces and fought our socialist armies. Some of these men have since fled Brazil or have been hiding on the countryside. A great number of 'closet conservatives', however, are still within our armed forces, and may become a great source of problems in the future. Our security services have suggested a 'cleaning operation' on our officer corps.
Arrest or exile all unloyal generals
Exile only the most dangerous men
It would be better if we seek reconciliation with them
A New Constitution

After our victory in the civil war, some in our government have raised the possibility of calling up a new Constitutional Assembly. This new document would legally consolidate the socialist character of Brazil, and also ensure some of our projects for the next years.
Call up a constitutional assembly
There's no need for that
Constitutional Assembly: The new Brazil
No matter what happened, Brazil is still a Democracy!
Socialism is true Democracy - Proclaim the Peoples Republic of Brazil
Constitutional Assembly: The role of the States
Only a strong central government can ensure the establishment of Socialism
Smaller units are more manageable - favour more power for the states
Constitutional Assembly: The Legislative Branch

In order to really ensure that governance is directed by the working people and for the working people, there's been a proposal of replacing the Senate of Brazil with a grand Assembly of Trade Unions.
Maintain the present structure
Replace the Senate by an Assembly of Trade Unions
Relations with La Plata

Our relations with La Plata have been uneasy since our war in 1935. Over the past few years, they have become increasingly reactionary and intolerant regarding our socialist leanings. Some even say that a Second Platine War is just a matter of time.
We must be prepared for conflict against them in the future!
There is no need for this type of paranoia
Foreign policy initiative

South America is a dangerous place for Syndicalist countries. With the conservative forces in La Plata displaying signs that they will not tolerate a left-leaning Brazil existing right next to them, we should approach fellow socialist nations. Our natural partner, of course, is Bolivia - should we attempt even closer ties with them?
The Bolivians are our friends, we should stick together
We have our own internal issues to worry about
The Brazilians offer an alliance

The Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs has called our ambassador in Rio de Janeiro for a conference. With our two countries so closelly cooperating in several matters, a military alliance for our mutual protection against the rising reactionaries in La Plata is the next logical step.
Of course!
We have problems of our own, already
Mission to Bolivia?
As part of our strategy of strenghtening ties with the Bolivians, we have prepared a technical aid mission to La Paz, which will help them on establishing a new research institute.
Send technical aid to our Bolivian brothers!
What a waste of money!
Brazilian mission to Bolivia
A party of Brazilian technical specialists have just arrived in La Paz and are ready to establish a new research institute! This is a proof of Brazilian commitment to our continuing friendship!
Great
May Day declaration

Once again, this is International Workers' Day. This year's parade, however, won't be marked by positive speeches about how unemployment rates are falling and industrial output rising. Our president will instead adress how the people shall help the country in these times of international crisis and the apparently coming conflict with La Plata. Using this day to introduce the people to military drafts or anything of the like, however, would make many workers angry at us.
We must introduce drafts for the security of the country
Promote volunteer militias of workers
Do nothing, we aren't going to war anyway
Demobilize the Greenshirts
Send these men back to their civilian lives
These loyal militiamen will become the elite of our army
Demobilize the Forзas Pъblicas
We still have under our control thousands of troops from the State security forces, the Forзas Pъblicas. What should we do about them?
Send them back to their home states
Consolidate them on a new National Guard
These battle-hardened units may be useful on guarding our borders
A great officer purge

During the civil war, a great number of our officers sided with the enemy forces and fought our Integralist armies. Some of these men have since fled Brazil or have been hiding on the countryside. A great number of these 'closet socialists', however, are still within our armed forces, and may become a great source of problems in the future. Our security services have suggested a 'cleaning operation' on our officer corps.
Let the purges begin
It would be better if we seek reconciliation with them
Relations with the Patrianovistas

The Patrianovistas, who now are officially the catholic-traditionalist branch of the Integralist movement, are asking us to clarify their role on the new Integralist state. Specifically, they want to know what approach we are going to take towards the Catholic Church.
Religion is superstition and nothing more
The Church and the Catholics are our friends
A New Constitution

After our victory in the civil war, some in our government have raised the possibility of calling up a new Constitutional Assembly. This new document would legally consolidate the Integralist character of Brazil, and also ensure some of our projects for the next years.
Call up a constitutional assembly
There's no need for that
Constitutional Assembly: The new Brazil
Mantain at least a faзade of Democracy
Integralism is the only valid choice
Constitutional Assembly: The role of the States
Promote a strong central authority
Favour more power for the states
Constitutional Assembly: The Legislative Branch

In order to ensure the establishment of our Integralist corporate state, all branches of our society should have a voice in the government. A great part of our cabinet has proposed replacing the Senate with a Chamber of Corporations, made of representatives from the different sectors of trade, industry, agriculture and trade unions of Brazil.
Maintain the present structure
Replace the Senate with a Chamber of Corporations
Constitutional Assembly: The role of the Church

Under pressure from the Patrianovista branch of Integralism, some congresspeople are debating on the status of the Catholic Church in Brazil. Should we reaffirm the Christian character of the Brazilian nation and declare Catholicism our official religion? Our should we instead follow a path of secularism?
Brazil is a secular state
Roman Catholicism is the state religion of Integralist Brazil
New military policies
We must introduce drafts for the security of the country
Promote volunteer citizen's militias
The Party offers their Greenshirts to the regular army
Do nothing - we must do whatever is possible to avoid war
Demobilize the Forзas Pъblicas
We still have under our control thousands of troops from the State security forces, the Forзas Pъblicas. What should we do about them?
Send them back to their home states
Consolidate them on a new National Guard
These battle-hardened units may be useful on guarding our borders
Dealing with the extremists

Our fragile democracy was nearly brought to its knees during the Brazilian Civil War. Our security services have, however, for the past months kept track of a number of subversive elements infiltrated on various posts across the military and all levels of government.
Go after all those who threathen our democracy
There's no need for that, let the dust settle
Police raids the AIB

Our security services have today raided a clandestine meeting of the Brazilian Integralist Action. The top cadre of their party is now under our custody, and we know that many of them were directly involved on the uprising against our government. What should we do? Should we arrest these main leaders? Or should this be just the beginning of a greater, major crackdown on the AIB?
Lock them in jail! Lock them all!
Arrest their main leaders only
The Socialist Movement in Brazil

Before the Brazilian Civil War, we have been promoting a campaign of repression against the trade union movement and the socialist-communist political parties. Now, however, we know the socialist movement did not take any major part on the uprising - in fact, many left-leaning workers and intelligentsia participated in the fighting against the undemocratic forces. Now, should we extend them an olive branch and rehabilitate their leaders and organizations? Or do we keep considering them a source of trouble?
Syndicalism is a destabilizing force, keep their parties illegal
Rehabilitate them, no need for that on a democracy
Cleasing the armed forces

During the civil war, a great number of our officers sided with the enemy forces and fought our loyal armies. Some of these men have since fled Brazil or have been hiding on the countryside, with a handful even staging a few terrorist acts against us... A great number of these men, however, are still within our armed forces, and may become a great source of problems in the future. Our security services have suggested a 'cleaning operation' on our officer corps.
Get rid of the socialist-sympatizing officers
Arrest and exile the nationalist-Integralist generals
Expel extremists from both sides
We should not weaken our officer corps... Do nothing
May declaration
Today, our president will adress how the people shall help the country in these times of international crisis and the apparently coming conflict with La Plata.
We must introduce drafts for the security of the country
Do nothing, we aren't going to war anyway
Banco Bradesco
Today Amador Aguiar founded the Banco Bradesco in Marilla, Sao Paulo. This will benefit our economical situation
Huzzah!
Demobilize the Forзas Pъblicas
We still have under our control thousands of troops from the State security forces, the Forзas Pъblicas. What should we do about them?
Send them back to their home states
Consolidate them on a new National Guard
These battle-hardened units may be useful on guarding our borders
Dealing with the extremists

Our Republic was nearly brought to its knees during the Brazilian Civil War. Our security services, however, have for the past months kept track of a number of subversive elements infiltrated on various posts across the military and all levels of government. Our forces are just awaiting our orders to initiate the arrest orders of these men and women.
Go after all those who threathen our nation
There's no need for that, let the dust settle
Police raids the AIB

Our security services have today raided a clandestine meeting of the Brazilian Integralist Action. The top cadre of their party is now under our custody, and we know that many of them were directly involved on the uprising against our government. What should we do? Should we arrest these main leaders? Or should this be just the beginning of a greater, major crackdown on the AIB?
Lock them in jail! Lock them all!
Arrest their main leaders only
The Socialist Movement in Brazil
As we continue our campaing against the enemies of Brazil, should we take action against the socialist parties?
Syndicalism is a destabilizing force, keep their parties illegal
No need for this kind of repression
The Cohen Plan is discovered
Rubbish! That's just a piece of forgery
This could be a nice excuse
The Cohen Plan is made public

Today, our president Getъlio Vargas, on a nationwide radio broadcast, has announced the discovery of an extremist socialist plot to overthrow the Brazilian government. According to him, the State is now ready to round up even more dissidents to guarantee the safety of the people.
Announce a series of extraconstitutional security measures
Abandon this plot
Cleasing the armed forces

During the civil war, a great number of our officers sided with the enemy forces and fought our loyal armies. Some of these men have since fled Brazil or have been hiding on the countryside, with a handful even staging a few terrorist acts against us... A great number of these men, however, are still within our armed forces, and may become a great source of problems in the future. As part of the new set of security laws, some have suggested a 'cleaning operation' on our officer corps.
Get rid of the socialist-sympatizing officers
Arrest and exile the nationalist-Integralist generals
Expel extremists from both sides
We should not weaken our officer corps... Do nothing
The New State

With security measures taking effect, Vargas is ready to increase his control over the government even further and transform Brazil de jure into a dictatorship. A new set of laws being prepared would dissolve the present Constitution, the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies, and install federal interventors in all State governments, while also shuting all political parties. This new phase of the Republic will be termed the Estado Novo - the New State!
Proclaim the Estado Novo
Back down from this initiative
Federal interventions

As the Estado Novo dictatorship is being consolidated, more initiatives are showing up to centralize authority in Rio de Janeiro and limitting autonomy of the local oligarchies in the States. Should we now replace all State governors with federal-appointed interventors?
Promote a strong central authority
No need for these measures
Presidential border tour
Our president is willing to tour the southern states and review our troops stationed there. That would surelly raise the morale of our soldiers!
Do it
Nah
Heitor Villa-Lobos's tour
In order to ease tensions in these times of crisis, famous composer Heitor Villa-Lobos has approached us to sponsor a tour of his orchestra.
Sponsor him
Don't do it
O Petrуleo й Nosso!

Famous journalist Monteiro Lobato has launched a campaign named 'O Petrуleo й Nosso' ('The Oil is Ours'), aiming at pressuring our government in funding oil drilling. Our petroleum industry nowadays is limited to a few wells on Rio Grande do Sul. According to Lobato, however, large reserves may exist in the north and the northeast.
Oil? Here in Brazil? Nonsense!
Provide funding for his campaign
Oil found in Bahia

A drilling operation funded by Monteiro Lobato's 'O Petrуleo й Nosso' campaign has discovered a small oil reserve - coincidently, in the city of Lobato, Bahia. This small well may produce just a small ammount of oil daily, true, but it's the proof that many reserves may exist elsewhere in the country.
And people thought we were crazy...
The oil industry in Brazil

Over the last few years, Monteiro Lobato's 'O Petrуleo й Nosso' campaign has funded the exploitation of many small oilfields all arround the country. It is now time, however, to formally regulate this sector of our economy. Should we institute a state monopoly on the oil industry, or should we open these operations to foreign companies?
Create a new, state-owned company
Allow foreign companies to run the fields
A new capital?

Since our colonial era, there have been proposals of moving the Brazilian capital from Rio de Janeiro to our central hinterlands. This idea was formalized by our 1891 Constitution, which contained an article proposing transfering our seat of government to the state of Goiбs. Over the past decades, with major unrest and riots taking place in Rio, but also citing strategic reasons, some politicians have over time advocated this idea as well.
We shall build a new capital and name it 'Brasнlia'
No, Rio de Janeiro shall remain our capital
The Brasнlia Comission

Our government has decided to fulfill an article from the constitution of 1891 and move the Brazilian capital to a place close to the center of the nation. Our Ministry of Industry will setup a comission of several companies and government organs in order to comence construction work in the new city of Brasнlia. If everything goes according to the plan, it is expected that we will be able to move there in less than five years!
Good news! Setup the comission!
The Plano Piloto is presented

The Brasнlia Comission has presented to the public the plans for our new capital of Brasнlia. According to the so-called 'Plano Piloto', designed by the world-famous urbanist-architect duo Lъcio Costa and Oscar Niemeyer, Brasнlia will be a planned city of wide avenues, many open spaces and great monuments, capable of housing a population of 500 thousand. With the plans now setup, construction can start!
Great! Bring in the workers!
The Niemeyer scandal

Workers on the construction sites in Brasнlia and our cabinet in Rio de Janeiro were shocked today as a leading newspaper revealed that Oscar Niemeyer, chief-architect of our new capital, was a member of the old Brazilian Communist Party and has ties to the Brazilian Worker's Confederation, a major syndicalist opposition group. Due to the political implications of having a socialist building our new capital, conservative politicians are asking for his dismissal.
What an absurd! Replace him with Osvaldo Bratke!
Who cares? As long as he does his job...
The construction of Brasнlia

Just a few years ago an empty land, the future site of Brasнlia is being transformed. Land grading works are already taking place as the first residential quarters are built. The population of the area is also increasing, as thousands of workers arrive each month. If the pace is kept, we will be able to completelly transfer the capital by 1959. The transfer of the capital to the interior will also help developing the greater midwest of Brazil.
Good!
The costs of Brasнlia

Thousands of workers are arriving every month to work day and night on Brasнlia. Hundreds of rail lines and roads were built over the past years to service this empty region. Even so, most construction material must be brought from outside. This is causing the costs of Brasнlia to go extremely high... A parliamentary comission will be formed to investigate any case of overbudgeting and other financial misdemeanors.
I didn't know it would cost that much!
Brasнlia near completion

Our new capital is aproaching completion! Most government buildings are going to be finished by the end of the year, as are the residential and commercial sectors. As the population has reached 64.000, new residential suburbs are also being planned for the future. Even if the asphalt will only reach the main avenues by next January, our government has set April 20th as the day for inauguration of Brasнlia.
Great!
The foundation of Brasнlia

A beacon of civilization is now shining in the heart of South America. Today, our President has inaugurated our new capital, Brasнlia: a new, planned city of monumental modernist buildings, wide avenues and great open spaces. Government offices
Pack your bags, we're moving!

1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions

Workers and Peasants from all over the country answered the call of our government and gathered today in Rio de Janeiro for the 1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions. Delegates from all trade unions, collective farms, factories, army regiments, universities and cities will, for the next several days, debate and vote on many key issues for the fulfillment of the socialist revolution in our great nation!
Isn't this great?
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Paraguay

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Paraguay, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in the main cities of this former Platine Union Republic has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Paraguay
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Uruguay

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Uruguay, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in Montevideo has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Uruguay
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Bolivia

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Bolivia, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in La Paz has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Bolivia
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Argentina

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Argentina, under a military occupation since they were defeated in the Platine War. The people in the major cities of the country has been protesting since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security greatly depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Argentina
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - War Policies

The first issue presented to our delegates on this congress deals with the current conflict against La Plata. In order to deliver a major blow to their armies, we must make some sacrifices on the home front. The PSR supports calling up our reserve forces, thus increasing our avaiable manpower. This would decrease the ammount of men supporting our war effort on the industries and fields, however. The BOC and CBT, instead, preffer calling up volunteer militias.
PSR - Call up the reserves
BOC/CBT - Promote volunteer proletarian units
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - Industrial reforms

Since our march towards Socialism began, the industrial reforms have been granted much atention, as we swept aside the vestiges of the oligarchs and put all efforts to the benefit of the workers and the people. But the reforms must not stop! Our three main parties have put forward their own proposals on how they must continue.
BOC - We must strenghten the cooperatives
PSR - Promote limited private initiative
CBT - Industrial development must always be guided by the State
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The New President

The main issue for the delegates today is the selection of our next president. The main syndicates and parties have put forward their candidates: The BOC (Bloco Operбrio e Camponкs, Workers and Peasants Bloc) is represented by Lнvio Xavier. The PSR (Partido Socialista Revolucionбrio, Socialist Revolutionary Party) is under Joгo da Costa Pimenta. The CBT (Confederaзгo Brasileira dos Trabalhadores, Brazilian Worker's Confederation), meanwhile, has chosen Avelino Fуscolo.
BOC - Lнvio Xavier
PSR - Joгo da Costa Pimenta
CBT - Avelino Fуscolo
1st. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The President of the Council

Lнvio Xavier of the BOC was chosen by the Congress as the new President of the People's Republic of Brazil! However, while the President is our Head of State, power must actually be shared with the President of the Council. This is a nice opportunity to engage in a coalition with one of the other parties, or even appeasing the military by granting the post to a left-wing Tenentista officer.
Enter a coalition with the PSR's Joгo da Costa Pimenta
Invite Avelino Fуscolo of the CBT to the post
Grant the position to General Luнs Carlos Prestes
No need for a coalition, Lнvio Xavier will accumulate both posts

2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions

Today, representatives of the Brazilian people have gathered in Rio de Janeiro for our second Congress of Trade Unions. For the next days, these delegates will debate and vote on several very important political issues for the future of our revolution.
Isn't this great?
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Paraguay

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Paraguay, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in the main cities of this former Platine Union Republic has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Paraguay
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Uruguay

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Uruguay, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in Montevideo has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Uruguay
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Bolivia

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Bolivia, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in La Paz has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Bolivia
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Argentina

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Argentina, under a military occupation since they were defeated in the Platine War. The people in the major cities of the country has been protesting since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security greatly depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Argentina
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - Our mastery over Argentina

The government of Argentina is bound to us by a series of unequal treaties, granting Brazil a series of exclusive rights and much influence over their affairs - in effect making them merely our puppet. This has been a source of great discontent, however, and the delegates of the PSR and BOC wish to terminate these treaties, keeping them alligned to us as through a defense pact. The hawkish faction of the CBT, however, wishes to continue the status quo.
CBT - The present arrangement is just fine
PSR/BOC - End the unequal treaties, welcome them into our alliance

2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - Reforming the Air Forces

Despite our victory in the Platine War, we learned a good lesson: Our Air Forces are in a complete state of dissaray, without a clear path of development. Military leaders have put forward their own proposals on how to better develop the air arm of our forces.
Epaminondas dos Santos - an independent Air Force
Salgado Filho - Army Aviation Corps
Agilberto Vieira - Naval Aviation
Can't we just keep everything as it is?
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - Broadening the Land Reform

Our first land reform efforts, back in 1936, have granted us great results. Now, Brazil is ready for a new round of reforms. Delegates of the BOC want to create new peasant-headed cooperatives to develop several still-unused plots. The CBT supports instead the expansion of the state-owned farms, even if it means the dissolution of some cooperatives. The PSR, however, wish to slowly reintroduce some forms of private ownership of farmland.
BOC - Promote new peasant-headed cooperatives
CBT - Create more state-owned farms
PSR - Slowly introduce limited private initiative
Can't we just keep everything as it is?
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The New President

The main issue for the delegates today is the selection of our next president. The main syndicates and parties have put forward their candidates: The BOC (Bloco Operбrio e Camponкs, Workers and Peasants Bloc) is represented by Minervino de Oliveira. The PSR (Partido Socialista Revolucionбrio, Socialist Revolutionary Party) is under Edgard Leuenroth. The CBT (Confederaзгo Brasileira dos Trabalhadores, Brazilian Worker's Confederation), meanwhile, has chosen Astrogildo Pereira.
BOC - Minervino de Oliveira
PSR - Edgard Leuenroth
CBT - Astrogildo Pereira
2nd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The President of the Council

Minervino de Oliveira of the BOC was chosen by the Congress as the new President of the People's Republic of Brazil! While the President is our Head of State, however, power must actually be shared with the President of the Council. This is a nice opportunity to engage in a coalition with one of the other parties, or even appeasing the military by granting the post to a left-wing Tenentista officer.
Enter a coalition with the PSR's Edgard Leuenroth
Invite Astrogildo Pereira of the CBT to the post
Grant the position to General Luнs Carlos Prestes
No need for a coalition, Minervino de Oliveira will accumulate both posts

3rd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - Naval reforms

Another lesson we learned following the Platine War is regarding the state of our navy, which also lacks a clear path of development. Two main wings have developed amongst our naval officers: one arround Ernвni do Amaral Peixoto, who wishes to create a blue water navy capable of rivalling any major foreign fleet, and another one led by Jorge Dodsworth, who instead preffers on developing a minor green water fleet.
Jorge Dodsworth - We need a navy for protecting our local interests
Ernвni do Amaral Peixoto - We must strive for control of the South Atlantic
We are happy with our current model
3rd. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - A New Capital

Since our colonial era, there have been proposals of moving our capital from Rio de Janeiro to our central hinterlands. The idea was formalized by our 1891 Constitution, which proposes transfering our government to a new city in the state of Goiбs. Our delegates are now debating the issue: the CBT and PSR support the idea on the grounds of national defense, while the BOC states this will alienate the masses from the political discussions.
CBT/PSR - We shall build a new capital and name it 'Brasнlia'
BOC - No, Rio de Janeiro shall remain our capital

The PSR (Partido Socialista Revolucionбrio, Socialist Revolutionary Party) is under Josй Oiticica. The CBT (Confederaзгo Brasileira dos Trabalhadores, Brazilian Worker's Confederation), meanwhile, has chosen Zenon de Almeida.

PSR - Josй Oiticica
CBT - Zenon de Almeida

Expand our present facilities in Rio de Janeiro and Santos

PSR/BOC - We do not need this kind of repression

6th. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - The situation in Paraguay

An important issue presented before our delegates is regarding the present situation in Paraguay, under a military occupation since the end of the war against La Plata. The people in the main cities of this former Platine Union Republic has been protesting ever since our occupation began, a situation that may soon escalate into major riot. What should we do now? The hawkish faction of the CBT wants to continue the occupation, while the PSR and BOC defend their independence.
CBT - Keep up the occupation - Our security depends on this
PSR/BOC - We must listen to their demands - Independence for Paraguay

6th. Brazilian Congress of Trade Unions - Our mastery over Argentina

The government of Argentina is bound to us by a series of unequal treaties, granting Brazil a series of exclusive rights and much influence over their affairs - in effect making them merely our puppet. This has been a source of great discontent, however, and the delegates of the PSR and BOC wish to terminate these treaties, keeping them alligned to us as through a defense pact. The hawkish faction of the CBT, however, wishes to continue the status quo.

Since the XIXth century, Haiti and our Republic have considered themselves rivals over political mastery of Hispaniola. Over the past few decades, a large Haitian minority has settled on the border areas of the Dominican Republic, often being accused of criminal activity. Under the current dictatorship of Rafael Trujillo, this 'anti-haitianismo' policy has gained much ground, including promises for further 'dominicanization' of the border areas - that is, the forced eviction of Haitian settlers.
Continue the Anti-Haitian policies
We'd better cease this persecution
Massacre in Bбnica

Over the past months, our president Rafael Trujillo has steped-up his anti-Haitian policies, including giving security forces a free-reign on dealing with illegal migrant workers on the border areas. Today, in Dajabуn, he has declared that the 'Haitian question' is being solved, as army troops have massacred roughly three hundred Haitians settlers in the border town of San Francisco de Bбnica.
Praise the officers who took part on the operation and continue our repressive policies

The 1937 Congressional Syndicalist Union

The third Congressional Syndicalist Union has started, and there are three parties that represent our great nation. The Partido Socialista, which espouses a blend of British Syndicalism and Zapatismo. There is also the Partido de los Trabajadores, which is currently in power and supports Orthodox Syndicalism. Finally, there is the Partido Reformista, which supports Social Democracy. Which party will gain a majority?...
Let's get to work!
Internal economic development

The first policy that is under question is that of internal economic development. The Socialists wish to maintain the status quo, the Worker's Party wish to centralise the economic decisions and the Reformists wish to expand the collective's autonomy.

column2: Memento mori
The Andean Pact - A democratic alliance in South America

The situation in South America is grim, as the two major powers of the continent - Brazil and La Plata - are under control of extremist governments, with the minor nations of the region falling on their spheres of influence. As a second Brazilian-Platinean war sits just around the corner and several minor border disputes are ecloding on this otherwise calm region, the relativelly stable Colombia has begun to craft an alliance of democratic nations to serve as a bulwark against extremism.
Give them our support
We're not interested in South America
Canada praises our efforts
The government of Canada has recognized our efforts at crafting an alliance of democratic nations in South America. They have officially congratulated us on our initiative!
Oh, that's great!
Colombia and Peru at war

The democratic governments of Colombia and Ecuador are under attack from the expansionist Peruvians. The Andean Pact is the only bastion of democracy on an otherwise unstable continent, marked by extremist dictatorships - it is our moral duty to help them!
Keep up our word - send materiel and volunteers to Colombia
Help Colombia - send strategic materiel to the Andean Pact
Why help the Colombians? They're doomed anyway!
Support from the Entente

The Canadian government has kept up with their promise and have sent us a large quantity of capital and strategic materials to help on our war effort, as well as a large number of volunteers from their own armed forces.
Great!
Support from Canada
The Canadian government has kept up with their promise and have sent us a large quantity of capital and strategic materials to help on our war effort.
Great!
The end of the Colombia-Peru War

Our men have fought well at the jungles and mountains of Colombia, Peru and Ecuador, defending the democratic governments of the Andean Pact, and today they are returning home. Great parades and celebrations are organized on our streets, and our own chiefs of staff are attempting to analyze the lessons we have learnt in military matters.
Great!
Syndicalism spreading in America!

The increasing power of the Combined Syndicates of America has been of great concern to the Cuban government. President Vinageras fears now that the CSA controls large parts of the former USA's south and east, Cuba will soon be threatened by the godless Syndicalists. With the USA shattered, our nation needs to look for new allies.
Only Canada can protect us from the Syndicalists!
column9: Только Канада сможет защитить нас от синдикалистов!

column2: Cuba can protect itself!
Cuba asks for protection

The increasing power of the Combined Syndicates of America has been of great concern to the Cuban government. President Vinageras fears that, now that the CSA control large parts of the former USA's south and east, Cuba will soon be threated by the godless Syndicalists. With the USA shattered, Cuba pleads for our protection.
We can always use a new ally
Alright, but Cuba must join the Carribbean Federation
column9: Хорошо, но Куба должна войти в состав Карибской Федерации

column2: We can't protect Cuba...
Cuba is left alone

We have been informed that Cuba asked the Entente for protection against us, but the talks led to nothing and Cuba is now standing alone. Should we sponsor a syndicalist coup and install a friendly government?
column9: Нам сообщили, что Куба обратилась к Антанте, пытаясь заключить союз против нас, но переговоры ни к чему не привели, и Куба теперь осталась одна. Мы можем попытаться устроить на Кубе социалистическую революцию.

column2: Yes, sponsor a coup!
No, we don't care about Cuba
Join the Carribean Federation?

The Canadian government has offered us to join the Entente, but we are required to become part of the Carribbean Federation. Cuba would retain its internal sovreignty, but matters concerning the military, economy, and foreign policy would be decided by the federal government in Georgetown.
Never! We are a free and independent nation
We have no choice, we can't fight the Reds on our own...
Alright, we'll join the Federation, but we want fair representation...
column9: Мы хотим полноценного представительства в Федерации

column2: Cuban Ministers in our Government?

Cuba has petitioned to join our Federation, but demands fair political representation in our government. Considering that Cuba's population is as large as the entire Federation's, the request seems resonable. But some of our ministers fear that that Cubans will dominate our government and the Federation.
The request is reasonable. Invite Cuban officials into our government
No, they will wait for an election
The Carribbean Federation Denied our Request
The bastards in Georgetown rejected our reasonable request. They have left us in the open, as a sacrificial lamb to be slaughtered by the godless Syndicalists
column9: Ублюдки из Джорджтауна отклонили наше разумное предложение! Они готовы оставить нас одних на растерзание синдикалистам.

column2: Damn them!
We have no choice, we can't fight the Reds on our own...
The syndicalist want to coup us!
The CSA sponsored a coup, the syndicalist opposition is trying to gain control of the government!
column9: ОСА поддержали переворот и синдикалистская оппозиция пытается получить контроль над правительством!

column2: The coup is a success!
The coup failed!
The coup failed!
The coup we sponsored is being crushed and the syndicalist dissenters are being imprisoned!
There's nothing else we can do!
Then it is war!
The annexation of Cuba!
After a brief war we finally annexed Cuba. We can now release them as a free state with a syndicalist government or we can keep the military occupation.
column9: Куба теперь под нашим контролем. Что нам теперь с ней делать?

column2: An independent Cuba
Military occupation is better!
Cuba joins the Carribbean Federation

The island of Cuba has joined our Federation. It will take some time until Cuba is completely integrated into our political system, and the leftist dissenters on Cuba are dealt with. But our influence and power is certainly growing.
column9: Куба присоединилась к нашей Федерации. Пройдет время, прежде чем Куба полностью вольется в нашу политическую систему и мы разберемся с левыми оппозиционерами. Но наши сила и влияние серьезно выросли.

column2: Freedom and prosperity for the entire Carribbean!
column9: Свобода и процветание для всех Карибов!

column2: For the revolution!
... nobody can see this...
A free syndicalist country!
The Spanish Language

With Cuba as a member of our federation, almost half of our citizens now speak spanish as their native language. Currently, our official language is English, but those of our citizens that speak spanish or french increasingly fear that their culture and heritage is being subdued and ignored.
English will stay the official Language of the Federation
column9: Английский язык останется единственным официальным языком

column2: The federal government will be multilingual!
A free Cuba?
Should we let Cuba completely free or should we keep their government under our control?
column9: Стоит ли предоставлять Кубе полную независимость?

column2: Cuba will be a completely free nation!
We better keep them under control!
Growing unrest

Large parts of the Cuban population have become disatisfied with the Federation's policies. Radical elements have spread vile propaganda that Cuba has become nothing but a Canadian colony. Syndicalists groups have staged demonstrations in Havana, and even acts of sabotage against federal facilites!
Break up the demonstrations! Not a single inch for the godless Socialists!
Don't escalate the situation. As long as the majority stays peaceful...
Gerardo Machado is dead!

Today the President and general of the Cuba Gerardo Machado died. He served in the Liberal Party Administration of Josй Miguel Gуmez. A day of mourning has been declared and Fulgencio Batista has become the new President of Cuba.

column2: May him rest in peace!

Syndicalism in Cuba

Despite Cuba being under reactionary dictatorships for several decades, a latent syndicalist movement exists there, centered around young figures such as Fidel Castro and Camilo Cienfuegos. They have asked for our support on training a revoluctionary cell which, they dream, will one day be able to bring their island towards the family of socialist nations.
Full aid shall be given
